When parturients are acutely ill, it may be challenging to differentiate etiologies based on the presence of tachypnea and tachycardia. The percentage saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen (SpO 2) is a noninvasive continuous monitoring that provides real-time information on peripheral oxygen saturation. It also provides indirect information on adequacy of pulmonary gas exchange, cardiac function, and intravascular volume status. There is a correlation between oxygenation measured by SpO 2 and invasive arterial blood gas. An arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO 2) of less than 60 mm Hg corresponds to SpO 2 of less than 90%.
44 Delivery units need to be equipped with and use continuous SpO 2 monitoring. Disposable low-cost SpO 2 finger probes are commercially available and need to be considered when multiparameter monitoring is not available. Moreover, knowing the PaO 2/FiO 2 ratio is useful in predicting the degree of lung compromise.
